preface.p:
The word discrete in the title of our course means separate; something that is not smooth.
In the study of discrete mathematics we will typically concern ourselves with discrete objects such as the integers, graphs, finite and countable sets. (In contrast, excluded from this are objects that may vary continuously, such as those ones covered in trigonometry, calculus, and Euclidean geometry.)

introduction.p: Many of the concepts you learned in your MAT102 course will be useful in MAT202; in this chapter we briefly review some definitions and results, and present some exercises to warm up for the rest of the course! Material in this chapter is based on MAT102H5 Introduction to Mathematical Proofs by Shay Fuchs.

section.title: Sets and Functions
section.p: A set is is just a collection of objects (where the order in which the objects are listed does not matter). The following set operations should be familiar to you: intersection A \cap B, union A \cup B, complement A^c, difference A \ \backslash \ B, and Cartesian product A \times B.
We also recall that proving the set A is a subset of the set B simply necessitates showing that any element of A can also be found in B.

statement.p: If A and B are sets in some universe U, then we say A is a subset of B, denoted by A \subseteq B, if (\forall x \in U)(x \in A \Rightarrow x \in B). We say that A and B are equal as sets if A \subseteq B and B \subseteq A both hold. This means that (\forall x \in U)(x \in A \Leftrightarrow x \in B).
Define A = \{k \in \mathbb{Z} : k = 6s + 3 \text{ for some } s \in \mathbb{Z}\} and B = \{m \in \mathbb{Z} : m = 3t \text{ for some } t \in \mathbb{Z}\}. Prove that A \subseteq B holds.

hint.p: Pick an arbitrary element in A, call it x. Then you know x = 6s + 3 for some integer s. Can you express x in the form 3t where t is an integer?

remark.p: Interval notation is used to refer to sets of real numbers. It is incorrect, for instance, to say that (-2,4) = \{-1,0,1,2,3\}, or that \{0,1,2,3,\ldots\} = [0,\infty). Watch your notation!

section.p: Later in the course we will learn techniques for counting objects and proving that two sets have the same number of elements; the notion of cardinality will be a useful tool to remember.

statement.p: Two sets A and B are said to have the same cardinality, written as |A| = |B|, if there exists a bijection between them.
We also say A has cardinality less than or equal to the cardinality of B, written as |A| \leq |B|, if there exists an injective function from A to B.
Prove that the set of odd integers O = \{\ldots,-3,-1,1,3,\ldots\} has the same cardinality as \mathbb{N}.

hint.p: Construct a bijection from O to \mathbb{N}.

statement.p: Let A be a set. The power set of A, denoted by P(A), is the set P(A) = \{X : X \subseteq A\}, that is, it contains all subsets of A.
Prove that if A is finite, then |P(A)| = 2^{|A|}.

section.title: Logic and Proof Techniques
section.p: Mathematical statements can typically be phrased as an implication P \Rightarrow Q, read as if P, then Q, where P or Q may be complex statements themselves that involve conjunctions (and), disjunctions (or), negations, quantifiers, even implications. There are various ways in which an implication can be proven true, and there is no hard and fast rule that dictates which proof method to use given a particular problem. In MAT102 you were introduced to the following proof techniques:

ul.li: Direct proof: Assume P is true, then prove Q is true.
Contrapositive: Assume \neg Q is true, then prove \neg P is true.
Contradiction: Assume the conclusion is false, then use this to arrive at a statement that contradicts one of the assumptions.

section.p: Many of these statements are quantified universally, which means it involves some variable (say n), and you need to prove the claim holds for all relevant values of the variable (say n \in \mathbb{N}). For 1, 2, and 4, for example, the relevant quantities are integers; the statements need to be proven for all integers.
We can use mathematical induction to prove that a statement is true for all natural numbers.

theorem.title: Principle of Mathematical Induction
theorem.p:
Let P(n) be a predicate defined for n \in \mathbb{N}. If the following conditions hold:
P(1) is true;
For all k \in \mathbb{N}, P(k) \Rightarrow P(k+1) is true.
then P(n) is true for all n \in \mathbb{N}.
One can also replace the second condition with the following:
b.* For all k \in \mathbb{N}, [P(1) \wedge P(2) \wedge \cdots \wedge P(k)] \Rightarrow P(k+1) is true.
This is called strong induction, where one assumes the induction step holds for all natural numbers from 1 to k in order to prove the claim for k+1.

section.p: Depending on what is being proved, one may need to make slight modifications to the standard technique: e.g. changing/adding to the base case, or skipping from k to k+2 in the case when one only has to prove the claim for every other natural number starting from the base case.

section.title: Integers and Divisibility
section.p: For completeness we restate here the definition of divisibility and the Division Algorithm.

statement.p: Let a \in \mathbb{Z} and b \in \mathbb{Z} \setminus \{0\}. We say that a is divisible by b, or b divides a, denoted by b \mid a, if there exists m \in \mathbb{Z} such that a = mb.
If b is not divisible by a, then we write b \nmid a.
We say that the natural number p is a prime number if the only natural numbers that divide p are 1 and p.
Let a,b \in \mathbb{N}. Then there exist unique q and r that satisfy all of the following: a = qb + r, q \geq 0, 0 \leq r \lt b.

Find q and r that satisfy the Division Algorithm for the following pairs of numbers a and b:
a = 140, b = 22
a = 22, b = 140
a = 735, b = 21
Given integers a and b not both zero, their greatest common divisor, denoted by \gcd(a,b), is the largest integer that divides both numbers.
We say that a and b are relatively prime if \gcd(a,b) = 1.
Apply the three techniques above to compute \gcd(220,360).

solution.p:
The Euclidean Algorithm performs the following steps:
360 \amp = 1 \cdot 220 + 140 220 \amp = 1 \cdot 140 + 80 140 \amp = 1 \cdot 80 + 60 80 \amp = 1 \cdot 60 + 20 60 \amp = 3 \cdot 20 + 0
The GCD is the divisor in the last line (where the remainder becomes zero).

statement.p: Let a,b \in \mathbb{Z}, not both zero. Then there exist m,n \in \mathbb{Z} such that am + bn = \gcd(a,b).

section.title: Reading and Writing Proofs
section.p: Proofs are a form of communication. They are used to argue (that a claim holds true); and sometimes explain (why a claim is true).

activity.p:
When writing proofs, one needs to be clear, complete, and correct. Comment on the three proofs below of the statement \text{Let } m \in \mathbb{Z}\text{. Then }m\text{ is even if and only if }m^3\text{is even}. Which one(s) is/are
convincing?
missing steps?
easiest to read?
correct?
Proof 1 (\Rightarrow) m = 2k \Rightarrow m^3 = 8k^3 = 2(4k^3), so m^3 is even.
(\Leftarrow) By contradiction. Assume m^3 is even but m is odd. Then m = 2k + 1 \Rightarrow m^3 =(2k+1)^3 = 8k^3 + 12k^2 + 6k + 1, which is odd.
Contradiction, so m must be even. So m even \Leftrightarrow m^3 even.
Proof 2 m \text{ even } \Leftrightarrow m = 2k \Leftrightarrow m^3 = 8k^3 \Leftrightarrow m^3 = 2(4k^3) \Leftrightarrow m^3 \text{ even}, hence proven.
Proof 3 We want to prove that m \text{ is even if and only if } m^3 \text{ is even}.

(\Rightarrow) First, we show m even \Rightarrow m^3 even.
If m is even, then we can write m = 2k for some k \in \mathbb{Z}. Then,
m^3 \amp = (2k)^3 \amp = 8k^3 \amp = 2(4k^3) . Since k \in \mathbb{Z}, then 4k^3 \in \mathbb{Z} as well, and so m^3 is even.
(\Leftarrow) Next, we prove that m^3 even \Rightarrow m even. To do this we prove the contrapositive: If m is odd, then m^3 is odd.

If m is odd, then there is a k \in \mathbb{Z} such that m = 2k + 1. Then
m^3 \amp = (2k+1)^3 \amp = 8k^3 + 12k^2 + 6k + 1 \amp = 2(4k^3 + 6k^2 + 3k) + 1 . Since k \in \mathbb{Z}, then 4k^3 + 6k^2 + 3k \in \mathbb{Z} as well. Therefore m^3 is odd.
This completes the proof.
